comment.body: Not yet, but I want to give it a try.
I would, but I find it really hard to finish any :-/
I used to with my sister, we had a lot of fun with it.
Looking forward to a better interface, but the functionality is exactly what I needed!

You could do it as follows: allow users to issue requests (i.e. user folder with file data.json which contains something like req:true), local script runs every x minutes and checks user submissions and the time they were signed. If anyone requested in past x minutes, wget the latest comic (or however you want to get it) and update xkcd.yo. Not claiming this is the best way, just showing one way it‚Äôs definitely possible.
I'll look into that! It's a scenario I hadn't tested yet. Should be easy to introduce a check as to whether the Demo hub is downloaded and offering to download it if it's not.
@Pexo: I'll look into it, but what I mentioned before is probably easier to do.
I'm interested in getting one, so I'd like to hear your impression.

It's something I plan to take into account for zerunet, I'm integrating Influx to monitor CPU, RAM, bandwidth so I can (in the future) track when and where things get out of hand. You'll have to be patient though, it can't even transfer files yet (I'm getting there though).

@Styromaniac: Yes, but integrating influx would allow keeping track meticulously of how much resources specific parts of the software use and visualize it. This would be useful during the development process for optimization and for end-users to know how much resources specific zites are using.

@Styromaniac: It's not an official branch, and it's me porting it. The source code is on the [Git Center zerunet repo](/14mVJrvB1XqtC4Aq55BmXyf9yXUN9iWwd8). I expect to have a prototype with basic functionality in about a month or so.
Luckily Rust is a language you don't need to debug much.
@Mg0: I think it's meant to be symbolic.
I2Pd is a good call, I2P (java edition) will kill your rpi no questions asked.
@draugrdeathlord@zeroid.bit: Maybe she meant that she could still browse ZeroNet in offline mode.
It's mostly because ARM and Java hate each other, don't know how much the actual I2P implementation plays a role.
@draugrdeathlord@zeroid.bit: Onion addresses still work without DNS, and there's a couple of clearnet trackers with just IP in the defaults as well.
Interesting, I presume you're on Windows, that definitely sounds like something that should be solved (can't expect everyone to defragment all the time). I think most devs are on Linux though.

It's not in a usable state yet. I plan to continue work on it, but I got demotivated after my normie test subject were unable to figure out how to use ZeroID and select a certificate. They didn't even have to install ZeroNet, I spinned up a proxy for them and a step-by-step manual with screenshots was included. I discussed this with some other ZeroNet developers on Matrix and we concluded that it would be best to develop a proxy plugin for normie-friendly user login, but I haven't done so yet.

Thanks for your interest, I'll see what I can get done this weekend! The one positive thing about taking a break is that I've figured out some improvements to the data design while working on 1+Gallery.

What do you mean by safety? Privacy-wise products are public, orders are private between the customer and vendor. The model assumes that the customer trusts the vendor, but the vendor does not have to trust the customer. Once the vendor "accepts" an order it is moved from the customers data file to the vendor's file so the customer cannot alter them anymore, but they can still access their order history.

- The first goal is that the vendor can process payments through PM, i.e. "Send me X BTC to this address.", "I did", "OK, I can confirm, here's your download link/your package has been sent/you can come claim your order at Y place"
- Once everything necessary for that is implemented I'll try to add an option to link your Paypal for processing orders.
- After that I'll look into public ledger cryptocurrencies like BTC, it should be easy to verify a payment for those by sending a request to a site.

Non-public ledger cryptocurrencies are off the table for me. I don't know how they work and I don't have the time to learn how they work. Merge requests will of course be welcome, and coming to an agreement e.g. "Send me X Monero.", "Ok, done!", "Thanks and here ya go!" will always be possible for those who wish to use such cryptos.

As for what the benefits are:
- You are not dependent on the whims of a company.
- No hosting costs.
- Nobody can suspend your hosting, cancel your payments.
- Easy setup, just clone and alter the settings.
- Complete control. Each shop is a separate zite.
- You can manage your shop while offline.

Disadvantages:
- **Non-ZeroNet users need to use a proxy**
- Javascript is slow which means that shops with a large inventory may get slow, but a lot of dedicated webshop software is so bloated that ZeroMarket may end up being faster anyway.
- While not strictly necessary, you should configure automatic backups yourself e.g. cronjob rsync.

@Aassddff ‚ú† Œ£ üáßüá∑ üëë: It's not finished yet, I'm planning to include private messaging so you don't have to switch to another Zite like ZeroMail. (again PM would only be between vendor and customer)
And maybe it shouldn't ever be.

@Kaffie: I have no doubt this can be improved upon. I'm maintaining ZN on many devices (including ones I don't own) and I've not seen such RAM usage, but most of them are shut down daily and start automatically. My own instance is using 1.5GB of virtual RAM and has been running for several days and my rpi3 has run it for over half a year only restarting recently due to a power outage.

From what I've learned porting ZeroNet to Rust I see no reason why RAM usage should increase over runtime, although of course the number of sites and the size of sites hosted matters. So it's either a bug, or there's something I've missed.
The any website part doesn't matter, that it's possible at all to install malware on a mobile phone over http is the scary part.
@ulrichard: can't this still be used over https as long as they control the website you are visiting?

My daily commute (in non-Corona circumstances) is about 25km, so 50km total (of which I do 15km by bike and 35km by train.)

If I had to do so by car and I could save 50% of my gasoline bill, that doesn't sound like a bad deal ... until you tell me the car costs $100,000.
@ulrichard: Hadn't thought about charging it at work. The one advantage of having a hybrid is that you can still instantly refill the fuel when urgent, but 27km is far too little.
welcome back I guess :-)
Welcome back!

The owner of a zite or hub has absolute control over that site and can choose to censor, but due to the structure of ZeroMe you can always start your own hub if you do not like the moderation on one. The network is censorship resistant, not the individual sites, but nearly all sites support free speech and the only bans I've seen were for spamming.

Interesting read, didn't get through all of it though. Reminds me a bit of Solar Roadways, Addyi and Theranos. The list of such scams keeps growing.

I find that the extra trackers are mostly useful on bad wifi connections. Sometimes the connections keep failing and ZeroNet doesn't attempt to reconnect fast enough so I end up with 0/30 trackers, but with added trackers it's more like 2/80 in those cases.
@styromaniac@zeroid.bit: Right, it could be when laptop switches between wifi connections. I don't have the problem often so I don't feel like I could give enough context in a report.
